DOC.HEAD: Indian Parliament Repeals Punjab Law
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has repealed a constitutional amendment that allowed the government to suspend basic human rights in Punjab state where Sikh extremists have killed more than 7,500 people in the past seven years. The decision, taken late Friday night in the final hours of the first Parliament session convened under Prime Minister V.P. Singh, was largely a goodwill gesture. The amendment, passed in March 1988 when Rajiv Gandhi was prime minister, would have expired March 30, 1990. Many of the measures imposed under it had already been lifted earlier by the Gandhi government in hopes of easing the Punjab situation. Singh has promised to seek a political solution to the Punjab problem and has already traveled to the rich northern farming state in hope of opening new talks with Sikh militants. Sikh extremists, advocating creation of an independent nation for their faith in Punjab, have killed at least 1,806 people in the state this year, including 25 since Singh took office Dec. 2. The victims include Hindus, the country's largest religious group, as well as fellow Sikhs considered traitors or non-supportive of the militant movement. Parliament's lower house voted 360-1 to repeal the 59th amendment to the Constitution, and the upper house cast a unanimous 140 votes in favor of repeal. The repeal will become effective as soon as it is accepted by President Ramaswamy Venkataraman, whose post is primarily ceremonial. Gandhi, who is now the opposition leader in Parliament, said earlier his Congress Party would not oppose repeal. The policy-making lower house, of which Singh and Gandhi are members, had 525 seats at stake in the November election. Singh's National Front and its allies have 277 seats, while the Congress Party has 193. The 59th amendment had allowed the government to declare a state of emergency in parts or all of Punjab, thereby enabling the government to invoke other anti-terrorism laws that permit arrest without charge and indefinite detention. These laws remain on the books. Singh, who is a Hindu like all of his predecessors as prime minister, led his National Front coalition through the November election with pledges to seek a political solution to Punjab. Sikhs, who have a slight majority in Punjab, have complained of discrimination against their faith and culture by Hindus. Nationally, Sikhs comprise only 2 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus account more about 80 percent. The Sikh faith has roots in both Hinduism and Islam.
